docs.snippet: IN most families, to tinker with the traditional Thanksgiving menu is to court disaster. Substituting mashed potatoes for the candied sweets, adding mushrooms to what had been for years a plain bread and herb stuffing or replacing pumpkin pie with...
docs.abstract: Food column on dishes to add to Thanksgiving menu that are different than usual dishes; recipes; drawing (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: IN most families, to tinker with the traditional Thanksgiving menu is to court disaster. Substituting mashed potatoes for the candied sweets, adding mushrooms to what had been for years a plain bread and herb stuffing or replacing pumpkin pie with pumpkin cheesecake can be risky business. Complaints may replace emptied plates.

headline.main: Adding to the Holiday Menu Without Risks

docs.snippet: PIES, pies, pies. That's all I thought about last Thanksgiving, and I'm thinking about them now, too. This year, I'm going to buy mine at Hacklebarney Farm in Chester. First on my list are the traditional lattice- topped and apple crumb; next, the...
docs.abstract: Fran Schumer column on eating in New Jersey; recommends pies and cider at Hacklebarney Farm in Chester and ambiance at Oldwick General Store; photo; also gives brief reviews of Johnny Rockets in Short Hills Mall and Sanctuary Cafe in Little Falls (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: PIES, pies, pies. That's all I thought about last Thanksgiving, and I'm thinking about them now, too. This year, I'm going to buy mine at Hacklebarney Farm in Chester. First on my list are the traditional lattice- topped and apple crumb; next, the velvety and perfectly spiced pumpkin, and finally, the walnut chocolate pie, which is really a great chocolate chip cookie set in a ton of butter that passes for crust. Since your guests will probably be too full to finish even a sliver, I would recommend freezing the leftovers in bite-size hunks and nibbling on the single morsels -- like candy -- whenever the urge strikes. And it will, often. This is really a one-of-a-kind pie. You need to call (as soon as possible) to place your order, and retrieve it by the Wednesday before Thanksgiving. But you should visit the area at other times and for other reasons, including the cider mill on the premises, which holds public demonstrations on weekends and holidays in season; the moody splendor of nearby Hacklebarney State Park, and the plain, cinnamon, powdered and especially pumpkin cider donuts produced by the bakery on weekends.

docs.snippet: ARMED with a blender or a food processor, there is no end to the inviting cold soups that can be concocted for summer. An alluring whiff of spice can enliven flavor, and colors -- ranging from pale pastels to ruddy vibrant hues -- delight the eye....
docs.lead_paragraph: ARMED with a blender or a food processor, there is no end to the inviting cold soups that can be concocted for summer. An alluring whiff of spice can enliven flavor, and colors -- ranging from pale pastels to ruddy vibrant hues -- delight the eye. These vegetable-based soups will have a smoother texture if passed through a fine strainer after being pureed in a food processor or blender. Because cold will mute the flavor, give the soups ample time to chill before final seasoning. Chilling the soup plates before filling them is another good idea.

headline.main: Blend Cold Soup for a Hot-Weather Lunch or Party

docs.snippet: IN THE GO-GO MONTHS OF SUMMER, WHEN HEAT and activities conspire against a midday meal, a long, leisurely lunch in the shade is more than a luxury.         Such a meal punctuates the day. And if the food is good and the wine flows freely, the dist...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN THE GO-GO MONTHS OF SUMMER, WHEN HEAT and activities conspire against a midday meal, a long, leisurely lunch in the shade is more than a luxury. Such a meal punctuates the day. And if the food is good and the wine flows freely, the distinction between morning and afternoon blurs into a happy memory.

docs.snippet: LIKE MANY PEOPLE WHO LOVE TO EAT and have a passion for the rituals of dinner, my friend Johanna experiences a certain ennui whenever she is called upon to eat with her fingers. After a backyard barbecue or picnic, she often feels deflated. And wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE MANY PEOPLE WHO LOVE TO EAT and have a passion for the rituals of dinner, my friend Johanna experiences a certain ennui whenever she is called upon to eat with her fingers. After a backyard barbecue or picnic, she often feels deflated. And while other people are serving their summer guests spirited buffets, Johanna is hauling out the good crystal and the china. She's serving dinner. I understand Johanna and her need for ceremony, especially in the summer, when the living is supposed to be easy. This is exactly what propels her in the opposite direction. Summer, she feels, should have distinctive moments -- quiet, intimate interludes that stand in sharp relief to the season's jocular mood. Some people have suggested that this need is neurotic. I don't think so. The impulse to give a quiet sit-down dinner on a warm summer night is not a desire for perfection, but an urge of the human heart.

docs.snippet: THERE IS LESS TO ERIC RIPERT'S COOKING than meets the eye. This amuses the 31-year-old chef, who did not set out at Le Bernardin to reverse the miracle of  the loaves and fishes. Still, no matter how complicated his seafood looks, or how intoxicat...
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE IS LESS TO ERIC RIPERT'S COOKING than meets the eye. This amuses the 31-year-old chef, who did not set out at Le Bernardin to reverse the miracle of the loaves and fishes. Still, no matter how complicated his seafood looks, or how intoxicating its aroma, in the end it all comes down to flavors pure and simple. Ripert explains this in his cursory way -- he cooks what he likes to eat; he doesn't follow trends; he prefers oils and broths to butter and cream not because it's stylish, but because in Andorra, where he grew up, that was the custom.

docs.snippet: THE fresh, vine-ripened tomatoes sold in every market and farm stand simplify lunch or dinner. A few of these lush beauties, plus garlic, herbs and other embellishments, can quickly dress some pasta for a meal.   Here are a few possibilities. The ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE fresh, vine-ripened tomatoes sold in every market and farm stand simplify lunch or dinner. A few of these lush beauties, plus garlic, herbs and other embellishments, can quickly dress some pasta for a meal. Here are a few possibilities. The linguine recipe calls for diced tofu, the bean curd high in soy protein that has been in the health bulletins.

headline.main: Add Tomatoes When Dressing Up Pasta

docs.snippet: THE official start of summer is several weeks away, but despite the calendar the season starts this weekend. Cooking and entertaining lighten up, becoming easier and more informal.    This calls for sandwiches. Of course, sandwiches are essential ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE official start of summer is several weeks away, but despite the calendar the season starts this weekend. Cooking and entertaining lighten up, becoming easier and more informal. This calls for sandwiches. Of course, sandwiches are essential for picnics and quick lunches, but given adequate embellishment, they can also move to the hors d'oeuvres platter, a weekend lunch for guests or a casual supper.

headline.main: Sandwiches Dress Up for Special Summer Occasions

docs.snippet: Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the puckish French-born chef and owner of the Jo Jo and Vong restaurants in Manhattan, is the enfant terrible of modern French cooking. A decade ago, he turned his back on traditional meat stocks and glazes and built a v...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the puckish French-born chef and owner of the Jo Jo and Vong restaurants in Manhattan, is the enfant terrible of modern French cooking. A decade ago, he turned his back on traditional meat stocks and glazes and built a vibrant and spare cuisine from juices, vinaigrettes, flavored oils and light broths. He juiced carrots, for instance, spiked the juice with cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg and cayenne pepper and doused it all on shrimp. He seasoned radish juice with chervil and used it on cod. He put ginger in pineapple juice and tenderized chicken. He reduced mushroom broth to a syrup and drizzled it over scallops steamed in artichoke broth. A juniper oil became a foil for pork chops; a sweet pepper oil a glaze for chicken.

docs.snippet: NEW YEAR'S EVE looms. A lovely intimate dinner, perhaps? A big open house? And what about New Year's Day? Brunch? An informal gathering with television tuned to bowl games?    There is still time to consider all this and, whether such plans have a...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YEAR'S EVE looms. A lovely intimate dinner, perhaps? A big open house? And what about New Year's Day? Brunch? An informal gathering with television tuned to bowl games? There is still time to consider all this and, whether such plans have already been made, to think about what to serve. Food for these occasions should be festive, flavorful and easy to prepare and serve. Dishes that can be assembled in advance and wait for the guests to arrive or that can stand the test of time on a buffet table are best.

headline.main: Duck Breasts Fit Well on Festive New Year's Menu
